data.title: Marketplace returns 500 for long extension search text
data.body:
Testing #34122

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Paste the following single line string in the extension search box:

```
Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on thebank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into thebook her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations init, ‘and what is the use of a book,’ thought Alice ‘without pictures orconversations?’So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for thehot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasureof making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up andpicking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ranclose by her.
```

**Bug**
Marketplace returns a 500:

```
{"$id":"1","innerException":null,"message":"TF400898: An Internal Error Occurred. Activity Id: 369ab7d1-92d2-4d0d-8c18-9e37d1606065.","typeName":"System.Data.SqlClient.SqlException, System.Data","typeKey":"SqlException","errorCode":0,"eventId":0}
```

data.title: HTML editor, highlight closing tag, instead of all tags.

` tag 3. All `
` and `
` tags are highlighted, and should not. Only the corresponding closing tag should be highlighted. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Pressing enter replaces spaces with tabs in C++ files

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open or create a new C++ file and insert the following code:

[ht] means a literal tab-character. A . (dot) means "visible space".

```cpp
namespace MyProgram {
[ht]class Debug_generator : public Generator,
[ht]........................public Visitor,
```
2. Place the cursor directly after `Visitor,` and press Enter. The file contents is changed to:

```cpp
namespace MyProgram {
[ht]class Debug_generator : public Generator,
[ht][ht][ht][ht][ht][ht][ht]public Visitor,
```
I want to indent with tabs but align with spaces, VScode shouldn't replace anything unless I've explicitly requested VScode to do so.

I have disabled everything related to formatting that I've been able to find in the settings.json file.

If I set the filetype to `Plain Text` the line is left unchanged but the new line still gets tabs inserted automatically. I do not want VScode to do this either.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [folding] Click in bottom part of editor expands last region regardless of where focus is

data.title: RelativePattern difference in behavior for single star glob patterns
data.body:
Testing #34831

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (e059563fb6b8905de79ac4c75be537bb6dc74f5f, 2017-09-27T09:56:06.042Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17004

---

Steps to Reproduce:

Try creating watchers for all ts files in the root folder (and not in sub folders) using `RelativePattern`:

```ts
const relativeWatcher = vscode.workspace.createFileSystemWatcher(
    new RelativePattern(
        vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders[0],
        '*.ts'))
relativeWatcher.onDidChange(x => console.log('relative change ' + x));

const globWatcher = vscode.workspace.createFileSystemWatcher(
    vscode.workspace.rootPath + '\\*.ts');
globWatcher.onDidChange(x => console.log('change ' + x));
```

**Expected**
Since a single star glob pattern is used, I initially thought these watchers should only fire when a top level ts file is changed. Changing a ts file is subfolder of the workspace should not trigger either.

**Actual**
The watcher using relative pattern is always fired, even when the ts file is in a subfolder.  The globWatcher is correctly only fired for ts files in the root

From the documentation of RelativeWatcher, I think this behavior is expected since the glob is only applied to the file. 

To get the glob `*` behavior, I also tried patterns such as:

```ts
 new RelativePattern(
        vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders[0],
        './*.ts')
```

and 

```ts
new RelativePattern(
        vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders[0],
        '\\*.ts')
```

Using these, the relative watcher is never fired.

data.title: Saving an unchanged file still writes it to disk
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (e059563fb6b8905de79ac4c75be537bb6dc74f5f, 2017-09-27T09:56:06.042Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17004

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an extension to creates a watcher on ts files:

```ts
const watcher = vscode.workspace.createFileSystemWatcher(
    new RelativePattern(
        vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders[0],
        '*.ts'))

watcher.onDidChange(x => console.log('change ' + x));
```

2. Open a workspace with this extension and browse to a ts file. Hit save a bunch of times

**expected**
The file has not changed and should not be written to disk here. No change even should be fired

**Actual**
On every save, we seem to rewrite the file to disk. This also triggers the on changed event each time

data.title: RelativePattern not limiting watching to workspace subdirectory
data.body:
#34831

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (e059563fb6b8905de79ac4c75be537bb6dc74f5f, 2017-09-27T09:56:06.042Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17004

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. 
```ts
    const watcher = vscode.workspace.createFileSystemWatcher(
        new RelativePattern(
            path.join(vscode.workspace.rootPath, 'sub'),
            '*.ts'))

    watcher.onDidChange(x => console.log('change ' + x));
````

2. Open a workspace and try editing and saving ts files in the root folder and then saving ts files under `sub`

**Expected**
Change only fires for ts files under `sub`

**Bug**
Change is fired for files under the root as well files under `sub`.

data.title: Arrow up / arrow down / indents
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-ins
- OS Version: win7x64

There is some `function`, and `for` in it, so when you do some `Enter`'s to move down and then press "**arrow up**" or "**arrow down**" - your caret position will "fall through" all indents to the left, so user has to press Tab every time, to move the caret where it should be.

Annoying.

GIF:
![auto-indent](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/30936552-e958a0e0-a3dc-11e7-8820-eccff0b2433f.gif)

data.title: WSL node debugging does not handle launch.json program paths with slashs correctly
data.body:
#34996

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (e059563fb6b8905de79ac4c75be537bb6dc74f5f, 2017-09-27T09:56:06.042Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17004
- Extensions: 

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. For a workspace:
```
package.json
sub/
    index.js
```

2. Create a launch.json: 

```json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "index",
            "useWSL": "true",
            "protocol": "legacy",
            "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}\\sub\\index.js"
        }
    ]
}
```

3. Launch the program

**Bug**

```
Error: Cannot find module '/mnt/c/source/vscode-smoketest-express/subindex.js'
```


Oddly the first backslash seems work

data.title: Git actions are gone!!!
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Built from master as of 9/27/2017 11am PST
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. The context menu for Git has only one entry "Install additional SCM providers"
2. Next to "CHANGES", the "Clean" and "Stage" buttons are gone
3. The button to view the diff on the editor group title is gone
4. All Git related commands from command palet is gone.

cc @joaomoreno

data.title: When no folder or file open, the debug play button should not be shown
data.body:
- Open a new VS Code window with no folder or file open
- Go to the debug viewlet.
- The gear icon is missing which makes sense as there is no workspace to create the launch.json file in
- The play icon is present. Clicking on it opens the "Select environment" action
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16890566/30930092-67ad050c-a375-11e7-8820-c9ae7adbc34c.png)

Choosing any option obviously would result in an error.

We should either not show the play icon at all or on clicking on it should show an error saying "no file/folder to debug" instead of showing the "Select environment" action

data.title: Markdown references links don't handle escapes
data.body:
From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/33714#event-1267713457

In a markdown file:

```
text [more info][aut\]osave] text

[aut\]osave]: /docs/editor/codebasics.md#saveauto-save
```

Does not detect `aut\]osave` as a link

data.title: Touchbar: Prev and next buttons doesn't switch to the expected editors
data.body:
When using the Prev and next buttons  in the touchbar, the actions doesn't seem to follow any particular order, but seems to jump around. I assume this is because of some internal ordering of open editors, but this doesn't match what I'd expect: If I press next I'd go to the next right editor tab, and back is the next left one.

![touchbar_prev_next](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/173559/30928640-f8344afe-a370-11e7-9826-6d1635ac0e13.gif)

data.title: Launch Multiple Windows on Different Desktops

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When launching VS code from a new virtual desktop on Windows, you are forced to the virtual desktop that has an active instance of VS code. 

I expect that it would render a new window for VS code in the new virtual desktop to let me have different projects open at the same time.

data.title: Clarify parameters with backticks in error messages
data.body: Also add missing 'id' to the duplicateView2 message.

data.title: Update ripgrep to 0.6.0+
data.body: #35236 depends on `--quiet` working with `--files`. We'll also need the fix for `--files` performance that is not in any release yet only in master.

data.title: Let workspaceContains trigger use rg --quiet
data.body:
Follow-up for #34823.

Using `--quiet` will avoid all output on stdout and `rg` will terminate by itself. This should further optimize the `workspaceContains` trigger.

Requires upgrading the Ripgrep version we ship because in the current `--quiet` doesn't work with `--files`.

data.title: Should not open save prompt when closing a tab when autosave is enabled (via files.autoSave to onFocusChange)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:26:20.018Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-59-generic
- Extensions: don't matter at all

---
Setting `files.autoSave` to `onFocusChange` seems to replicate IntelliJ's save as close as possible. To me this signifies that I don't want to manually save at all. However, when closing a tab that is currently dirty, VSCode displays a save prompt with "Cancel", "Don't Save" and "Save" buttons. I would expect it to automatically save as well.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `files.AutoSave` to `onFocusChange`.
2. Open any file.
3. Make any edit.
4. Close tab with the shortcut, e.g., for me this is Ctrl+w (don't open command palette, this already counts as a focus change)

Outcome:
* Save prompt opens.

Expected outcome:
* File is saved and editor is closed.

I guess this could be solved by either changing the behavior of `onFocusChange` or introducing a new value like `onFocusChangeOrClose`.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes
